title: Woman, 44, is shot when a dog inside car causes handgun to fire
text:
An Oklahoma woman was shot when a dog jumped onto a back seat console in a car, causing a gun to fire.

Tina Springer, 44, was in the passenger seat of the vehicle that had stopped Thursday to wait for a train in Enid, northern Oklahoma, when the incident occurred.

The yellow Labrador retriever, which belongs to Brent Parks, the 79-year-old driver, was in the back seat and jumped onto the folding console.

Scroll down for 911 audio

Tina Springer was in the passenger seat of Brent Parks' vehicle on Thursday when the incident occurred. The yellow Labrador retriever, which belongs to Parks, was in the back seat and jumped onto the folding console, causing the gun to fire a single shot

That's when the .22-caliber handgun under the console went off, sending a bullet into the woman's thigh.

In audio from the 911 call, Parks tells the dispatcher everything that happened.

'Well a gun went off. Got her in the leg. She didn't do it herself. I had a dog in here and he stepped on the gun,' Parks says.

'The dog shot her?' the dispatcher asked. Parks answered: 'Yea, he stepped on it and it went off. But anyway, can you get an ambulance out here.'

Meanwhile, Springer is heard in the background saying, 'I don't feel good' and 'tell my kids I love them'.

'She's bleeding pretty bad,' Parks is heard saying.

The then says that she needs to lay down.

'She's alert but she's losing blood bad. I'm trying to find something to wrap around her leg but she's a screaming and all this sh*t,' a frustrated Parks is heard saying.

In audio from the 911 call, Parks tells the dispatcher: 'A gun went off. I had a dog in here and he stepped on the gun.' The dispatcher asked: 'The dog shot her?' Parks answered: 'Yea, he stepped on it and it went off. But anyway, can you get an ambulance out here'

The dispatcher then asks Parks if he has a clean dry cloth. 'If I had a clean dry cloth it would've already been on her ma'am,' Parks retorts.

He then says he can use his belt and the dispatcher instructs him to make a tourniquet with the belt.

Police later determined that the cloth from the seat covers may have gotten into the trigger well of the gun, making it discharge.

Springer, who lives in Nash, Oklahoma, and is Parks' caretaker, was taken to a hospital for treatment.

Police say Parks told them the gun isn't usually loaded.
description: Tina Springer, 44, of Oklahoma, was shot on Thursday while she was riding in a truck with Brent Parks whose dog (file image) jumped onto the console and caused the gun to fire a single shot.
